content:
The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care to dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. The Secretary shall enter into partnerships to fund general legal services for homeless veterans, ensuring equitable distribution across the United States, including rural communities and tribal lands. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related legal assistance, family law support, income support services, criminal defense for issues related to homelessness, and other legal aid deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary may require periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness through partnerships with public and private entities. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include eligibility criteria for veterans receiving assistance or care in specific settings. Eligible veterans must be enrolled for care and meet certain conditions for a consecutive 60-day period. The subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include eligibility criteria for veterans receiving assistance or care in specific settings. Eligible veterans must be enrolled for care and meet certain conditions for a consecutive 60-day period, with breaks in care disregarded if not the veteran's responsibility. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017.

SEC. 7. Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness for eligible veterans and review efforts to enhance privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, which required annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans, is repealed.
